org.grouplens.lenskit.cursors

Class AbstractCursor<T>

  • java.lang.Object
    • org.grouplens.lenskit.cursors.AbstractCursor<T>
  • Type Parameters:
    T - The type of value returned by this cursor.
    All Implemented Interfaces:
    java.io.Closeable, java.lang.AutoCloseable, java.lang.Iterable<T>, Cursor<T>
    Direct Known Subclasses:
    AbstractPollingCursor, GroupingCursor

    public abstract class AbstractCursor<T>
extends java.lang.Object
implements Cursor<T>
    Base class to make Cursors easier to implement.

    Compatibility: Public

    • Method Detail

      • getRowCount

        public int getRowCount()
        Description copied from interface: Cursor
        Get an upper bound on the number of rows available from the cursor.
        Specified by:
        getRowCount in interface Cursor<T>
        Returns:
        the maximum number of rows which may be returned by Cursor.next(), or -1 if that count is not available.

      • fastNext

        @Nonnull
public T fastNext()
        Variant of Cursor.next() that may mutate and return the same object avoid excess allocations. Since many loops don't do anything with the object after the iteration in which it is retrieved, using this iteration method can improve both speed and memory use.

        This implementation delegates to Cursor.next().

        Specified by:
        fastNext in interface Cursor<T>
        Returns:
        The next element from the cursor, reusing objects if possible.
        See Also:
        Cursor.next()

      • fast

        public java.lang.Iterable<T> fast()
        Description copied from interface: Cursor
        Convert the cursor to an iterable whose Iterator.next() method is implemented in terms of Cursor.fastNext().
        Specified by:
        fast in interface Cursor<T>
        Returns:
        An iterable for fast iteration.

      • iterator

        public java.util.Iterator<T> iterator()
        Get the iterator. This method just returns this, so for-each loops can be used over cursors.
        Specified by:
        iterator in interface java.lang.Iterable<T>
        Returns:
        The cursor as an iterator.
        See Also:
        Iterable.iterator()
